suncertify.db
Class DBFileAccess

java.lang.Object
  suncertify.db.DBFileAccess

public final class DBFileAccess
extends java.lang.Object

Sole access point to the database file. All file-level access operations on the database file are bundled in this class. Not thread-safe. The class is designed as a singleton and as such to be accessed exclusively through the thread-safe singleton instance of the data access class Data.

Version:
1.0
Author:
Lars Kuettner

Method Detail

getInstance

public static DBFileAccess getInstance(java.lang.String databaseLocation)
                                throws DatabaseFileException
Factory method to get the Singleton instance of DBFileAcess through which all database file access operations have to be conducted.

This method may be called more than once provided the database location is the same every time. The instance is initialized upon the first method invocation.

Parameters:
databaseLocation - a string representing the path name to the database file
Returns:
the Singleton instance of DBFileAccess
Throws:
DatabaseFileException - if there is a problem with either the databaseLocation parameter or the database file the parameter refers to

matchDatabaseLocation

public boolean matchDatabaseLocation(java.lang.String databaseLocation)
                              throws DatabaseFileException
Compares the canonical representation of the database location path name with the (canonical) database location path name property.

Parameters:
databaseLocation - A string representing the path name to the database file
Returns:
a boolean value that is true if the canonical representation of the database location parameter matches the database location property, and false otherwise
Throws:
DatabaseFileException - if the canonical path cannot be retrieved

terminate

public void terminate()
Closes the random access file and marks the singleton instance as uninitialized so that it may be reused. This latter feature is particularly useful for testing purposes. The method will usually be called from the encapsulating Data class singleton instance.

iterator

public java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Long> iterator()
Provides an iterator over valid record numbers in the succession of their appearance in the database file. Only the records marked valid are considered. The records marked invalid are quietly skipped.

Returns:
an iterator instance conforming to the Iterator interface

readRecord

public java.lang.String[] readRecord(long recNo)
                              throws RecordNotFoundException,
                                     DatabaseFileException
Reads a single valid record from the database file and returns its fields.

Note that the record must be marked valid in order to be readable. An attempt to read an invalid (deleted) record would trigger a RecordNotFoundException.

Parameters:
recNo - the long value representing the record number that uniquely identifies the record to be read
Returns:
a string array representing the requested record
Throws:
RecordNotFoundException - if there is no valid record corresponding to recNo
DatabaseFileException - if the database file can't be accessed as needed

placeNewRecord

public void placeNewRecord(long recNo,
                           java.lang.String[] data)
                    throws RecordNotFoundException,
                           DatabaseFileException
Places a new record at a predetermined empty slot in the database file. There are no restrictions about the contents of such a record, even if this leads to records with identical contents in the database.

Knowledge about the re-assignability (emptiness) of a record slot must be managed from the outside. The record number recNo determines the slot. It is assumed that record numbers are assigned in ascending order, beginning with zero at the first record in the database file. Slots of records previously marked deleted may thus be recycled.

Parameters:
recNo - the long value representing the record number that uniquely identifies the record slot to be populated
data - A string array representing the fields of the new record to be written to the database file. The maximum length of a field is taken from the record metadata (schema), RecordMetaData. Any field that exceeds its maximum length is quietly truncated, with just a warning log message printed.
Throws:
RecordNotFoundException - if recNo is out of range, that is, less than zero or larger than the total number of records (valid and deleted together), or if recNo refers to a record that is not marked deleted
DatabaseFileException - if the database file can't be accessed as needed

updateRecord

public void updateRecord(long recNo,
                         java.lang.String[] data)
                  throws RecordNotFoundException,
                         DatabaseFileException
Replaces the contents of a valid record in the database file. A valid record may be updated without restrictions, even if this leads to several records with identical contents.

Parameters:
recNo - the long value representing the record number that uniquely identifies the record to be updated
data - A string array representing the fields of the new record to be written to the database file. The maximum length of a field is taken from the record metadata (schema), RecordMetaData. Any field that exceeds its maximum length is quietly truncated, with just a warning log message printed.
Throws:
RecordNotFoundException - if there is no valid record corresponding to recNo
DatabaseFileException - if the database file can't be accessed as needed

deleteRecord

public void deleteRecord(long recNo)
                  throws RecordNotFoundException,
                         DatabaseFileException
Deletes a valid record specified by its record number.

The deletion will be conducted so that the space the record occupied, together with its record number, may be subsequently reassigned to a new record.

Parameters:
recNo - the long value representing the record number of the valid record to be deleted
Throws:
RecordNotFoundException - if there is no valid record corresponding to recNo
DatabaseFileException - if the database file can't be accessed as needed
